Memories of my youth

Introduction

This is the most missed, painful, and failed youth I know, and it is my own time. Will the love of young people feel more and more childish as they get older? Or, if you still donâ€™t feel childish after a few years or more than ten years, itâ€™s just because you havenâ€™t grown up for so many years?

I have doubted myself and raised all kinds of questions of the above type to myself. But in the end, I found that what scares me the most is not the childishness of my personality, but my memory of that time is gradually disappearing, and it seems like two passers-by with the past. Still drifting away.

åŸæ–‡

è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘æ‰€çŸ¥çš„æœ€ä»¤äººæ€€å¿µã€ç—›è‹¦ã€ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æœ€å¤±è´¥çš„é’æ˜¥ï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¯å±äºæˆ‘è‡ªå·±çš„ä¸€æ®µæ—¶å…‰ã€‚å¹´è½»äººçš„çˆ±æ‹æ˜¯å¦ä¼šéšç€å¹´é¾„çš„å¢é•¿è€Œæ„ˆå‘è¢«è‡ªå·±è§‰å¾—å¹¼ç¨šï¼Ÿæˆ–è€…è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœå‡ å¹´ã€åå‡ å¹´ä¹‹åä½ ä»ä¸è§‰å¹¼ç¨šçš„è¯ï¼Œåªæ˜¯å› ä¸ºä½ è¿™ä¹ˆå¤šå¹´éƒ½æ²¡æœ‰æˆé•¿ï¼Ÿ
æˆ‘æ€€ç–‘è¿‡è‡ªå·±ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯¹è‡ªå·±æå‡ºè¿‡å¦‚ä¸Šç±»å‹çš„ç§ç§ç–‘é—®ã€‚ä½†ç»ˆç©¶æˆ‘å‘ç°ï¼Œæœ€ä»¤æˆ‘å®³æ€•çš„ä¸æ˜¯äººæ ¼çš„å¹¼ç¨šï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æˆ‘å¯¹é‚£æ®µæ—¶å…‰çš„è®°å¿†æ¸æ¸æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œä¼¼ä¹å’Œè¿‡å»åƒæ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªæ“¦è‚©è€Œè¿‡çš„è¡Œäººï¼Œå°±ç®—æˆ‘æåŠ›é©»è¶³åŸåœ°ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿä¾æ—§æ¸è¡Œæ¸è¿œã€‚

2017å¹´6æœˆå‰

æ•™å­¦æ¥¼è½¬è§’çš„ä¸€å»

Thatâ€™s probably something that happened after May, because I always remember it as an extremely relaxed period. This may go against common sense, but it is indeed my reality: in the last period of every â€œlearning phaseâ€ in life, like the last semester of primary school, the last four months of junior high school, and the last semester of high school, I actually work the hardest and tire myself out the most in the first two and a half months. Perhaps because Iâ€™m naturally not inclined to work hard, I always find it difficult to maintain a high-intensity study mode until the exam comes.

At that time, I had an acquaintance, or rather a classmate, named Wang Yunxi. Of course, thatâ€™s a pseudonym, I just made it up. If I canâ€™t remember his real name many years later, let it be forgotten.

We werenâ€™t very familiar, he seemed to be sitting in the first row, and I seemed to be a little further away, in the second or third row. But we had a little contact, that he was very good-looking, always caught my eye.

He liked to mess around with his neighbors on both sides. Fortunately, there was a girl sitting next to him that I was quite familiar with, so I had the opportunity to talk to him. Occasionally during breaks, I would pretend to be looking for people I knew around him and talk to him. But I still didnâ€™t have any â€œinappropriate thoughtsâ€ about him, okay, maybe there were some, but I just didnâ€™t want to think about them. After all, the chances of anything happening were probably slim.

Through my intentional or unintentional approaches, he gradually became more acquainted with me, but I found it strange and he probably did too - there was always a strange atmosphere between us. It wasnâ€™t ambiguous, but rather a kind of distance or familiarity, as if we were already â€œfamiliarâ€ classmates, but there was still a strange feeling lingering around us. Of course, this may not be surprising, as it was already nearing the time for the high school entrance exam, and everyone was more focused on studying for the exam.

However, I always seemed to have good luck at some critical moments. A month after I had feelings for him, during that busy and intense summer when we were preparing for the high school entrance exam, his mother wanted to take him out for lunch and do something else, so they had more break time than usual. He actually asked me, â€œDo you want to come with me?â€ This was really a â€œstroke of good fortune,â€ something that I couldnâ€™t refuse in junior high school, whether it was someone I liked or a unique break time. So of course, I agreed.

I forgot what he was doing that day, but I remember his mother took us to eat Zhang Liangâ€™s spicy hotpot. After we finished, we were supposed to go back to school. We got off the bus together and walked on a deserted path on the school campus. We were definitely late, but we had asked for leave, so we werenâ€™t in a hurry. It was probably around 2017 when I was in junior high school, and the sky was very blue, it was summer, the sun was warm, the strong wind was blowing, and we walked in silence. I knew that this seemed to be a parting. It wasnâ€™t just the unexpected break we had that afternoon, but also the end of junior high school life, and the result that would not come if we didnâ€™t do something about it.

So we walked through the campusâ€™ paths in silence, pushed open the schoolâ€™s 3-meter-high glass doors in silence, and climbed the stairs in silence - me walking, him walking. Our classroom was on the outermost side of the third floor, so close and yet so far. I couldnâ€™t stop him from moving towards our classroom without any reason or courage. But in the end, I was brave enough to do something. As he stepped onto the third-floor platform, I called out to him and said, â€œWait for me.â€ He waited for me. I asked him not to go ahead, and he continued to stand still, waiting for me to finish walking up the steps and onto the platform. I leaned in close, pretending to whisper something to him, and with a seemingly secret phrase, I gently brought my face close to his, closed my eyes, and quickly kissed him before running into the classroom.

I could see from the corner of my eye that he was suddenly stunned. When I entered the classroom, he seemed to still be standing there. My heart was beating so fast, and for the first time, I felt a sense of naive passion. Afterward, we spent the week talking and laughing as if nothing had happened.

Looking back now, I realize how shy and immature I was in my youth.

On that weekend, he invited me to his house as a guest. I went, and there happened to be no one there. I was curious about why he had asked me to come, but he didnâ€™t seem to have a reason and kept talking about random things. Perhaps he was giving me an opportunity of some sort. But unfortunately, in my confusion at the time, I missed it.

Later on, when we were in high school and the classes were randomly assigned, he posted a QQ status saying that he hoped we would be in the same class. At that time, I also felt something, but in the end, I was too afraid to ask, to say, or to face him.

In reality, we never saw each other again after the middle school entrance examination. We didnâ€™t end up in the same class in high school, and there was no magical reunion. The next time I saw him was after we graduated, and he had transformed from a thin and weak boy sitting in the front row to a tall and sturdy basketball forward. I wanted to say something, but he felt so unfamiliar to me that I didnâ€™t say anything at all.

Just like the tune of youth, it is a mix of the pleasure and pain of yearning for what cannot be obtained, a contradiction of unforgettable yet failed memories. Perhaps in this world, we each have our own snowfall, our own hidden and radiant facets.

entry.content:
Will the recent bank chaos lead to an economic crash?

So far, people seem remarkably blasÃ©

How quickly things change. A few weeks ago analysts were convinced the global economy was powering ahead. Now they worry about a deep recession caused by fallout from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (svb) and the rescue of Credit Suisse. â€œFrom no landing to hard landingâ€, as Torsten Slok, an economist at Apollo Global Management, an asset manager, has written. Analysts at JPMorgan Chaseâ€”better at economics than metaphors, one hopesâ€”say that â€œa soft landing now looks unlikely, with the airplane in a tailspin (lack of market confidence) and engines about to turn off (bank lending)â€.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸å¤§çš„å˜é©ã€‚ å‡ å‘¨å‰ï¼Œåˆ†æå¸ˆç¡®ä¿¡å…¨çƒç»æµæ­£åœ¨å¼ºåŠ²å¢é•¿ã€‚ ç°åœ¨ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æ‹…å¿ƒå› ç¡…è°·é“¶è¡Œ (svb) å€’é—­å’Œç‘å£«ä¿¡è´· (Credit Suisse) çš„æ•‘æ´è€Œå¯¼è‡´çš„ä¸¥é‡è¡°é€€ã€‚ â€œä»ä¸ç€é™†åˆ°ç¡¬ç€é™†â€ï¼Œèµ„äº§ç®¡ç†å…¬å¸é˜¿æ³¢ç½—å…¨çƒç®¡ç†å…¬å¸çš„ç»æµå­¦å®¶æ‰˜å°”æ–¯æ»•æ–¯æ´›å…‹å†™é“ã€‚ æ‘©æ ¹å¤§é€šçš„åˆ†æå¸ˆâ€”â€”æœ‰äººå¸Œæœ›ï¼Œä»–ä»¬æ›´æ“…é•¿ç»æµå­¦è€Œä¸æ˜¯éšå–»â€”â€”è¯´â€œè½¯ç€é™†ç°åœ¨çœ‹èµ·æ¥ä¸å¤ªå¯èƒ½ï¼Œé£æœºé™·å…¥æ··ä¹±ï¼ˆç¼ºä¹å¸‚åœºä¿¡å¿ƒï¼‰ï¼Œå¼•æ“å³å°†ç†„ç«ï¼ˆé“¶è¡Œè´·æ¬¾ï¼‰â€ã€‚

Evidence from before the recent banking chaos suggested that global gdp was increasing at an annualised rate of around 3%. In rich countries, job markets were on fire. So far there is scant evidence of a shift in â€œreal-timeâ€ data towards slower growth. A â€œcurrent-activity indicatorâ€ produced by Goldman Sachs, a bank, derived from a variety of high-frequency measures, looks steady. Purchasing-manager indices showed a slight improvement in March. Weekly measures of gdp produced by the oecd, a rich-country club, are holding up. ubs, another bank, tracks global gdp growth as priced by financial markets (in prices of oil and cyclical shares, for example). This currently indicates growth of 3.4%, versus 3.7% before svb collapsed.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

æœ€è¿‘é“¶è¡Œä¸šæ··ä¹±ä¹‹å‰çš„è¯æ®è¡¨æ˜ï¼Œå…¨çƒ GDP æ­£ä»¥ 3% å·¦å³çš„å¹´åŒ–é€Ÿåº¦å¢é•¿ã€‚ åœ¨å¯Œè£•å›½å®¶ï¼Œå°±ä¸šå¸‚åœºç«çˆ†ã€‚ åˆ°ç›®å‰ä¸ºæ­¢ï¼Œå‡ ä¹æ²¡æœ‰è¯æ®è¡¨æ˜â€œå®æ—¶â€æ•°æ®æ­£åœ¨å‘æ›´æ…¢çš„å¢é•¿æ–¹å‘è½¬å˜ã€‚ é«˜ç››é“¶è¡Œä»å„ç§é«˜é¢‘æŒ‡æ ‡ä¸­å¾—å‡ºçš„â€œå½“å‰æ´»åŠ¨æŒ‡æ ‡â€çœ‹èµ·æ¥å¾ˆç¨³å®šã€‚ é‡‡è´­ç»ç†äººæŒ‡æ•°åœ¨ 3 æœˆä»½ç•¥æœ‰æ”¹å–„ã€‚ ç”±å¯Œè£•å›½å®¶ä¿±ä¹éƒ¨ç»åˆç»„ç»‡ç¼–åˆ¶çš„æ¯å‘¨å›½å†…ç”Ÿäº§æ€»å€¼æŒ‡æ ‡ä¿æŒä¸å˜ã€‚ å¦ä¸€å®¶é“¶è¡Œ ubs è¿½è¸ªç”±é‡‘èå¸‚åœºå®šä»·çš„å…¨çƒå›½å†…ç”Ÿäº§æ€»å€¼å¢é•¿ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼ŒçŸ³æ²¹å’Œå‘¨æœŸæ€§è‚¡ç¥¨çš„ä»·æ ¼ï¼‰ã€‚ è¿™è¡¨æ˜ç›®å‰å¢é•¿ç‡ä¸º 3.4%ï¼Œè€Œ SVB å´©æºƒå‰ä¸º 3.7%ã€‚

It is still early days. The pain may be on the way. And as the JPMorgan analysts illustrated with their metaphor, economists have two worries. The first is uncertainty. If people fear a banking crisis and the accompanying economic pain, they may cut consumption and investment. The second relates to credit. Financial institutions, fearing losses, may pull back on lending, depriving firms of much-needed capital. Fortunately, though, there is reason to believe that the recent banking turmoil will have less impact than many fear.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

Take uncertainty first. Research published by the imf in 2013 finds that leaps in uncertaintyâ€”which had been caused by things like Americaâ€™s invasion of Iraq and bank collapsesâ€”can trim annual gdp growth by up to 0.5 percentage points, largely because firms delay investment. If such a hit were to materialise, global growth would fall from 3% to perhaps 2.5%.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

Yet unless the turmoil continues, the impact is unlikely to be that significantâ€”because the bank collapses made surprisingly little impression on people. A survey by Ipsos, a pollster, found that from early to mid-March American consumer confidence actually edged up, even as startups in Silicon Valley worried their money was going to vanish. An â€œuncertainty indexâ€ derived from analysis of newspapers by Nick Bloom of Stanford University and colleagues, rose a bit when the turmoil began, but is drifting back down. German business sentiment unexpectedly continued to improve in March. Global Google searches for terms related to â€œbanking crisisâ€ jumped in early March, but have also fallen again. It is hard to say why people are so blasÃ©. Perhaps after the past years of pestilence and war, ructions in the banking industry seem like a walk in the park. Or perhaps people think governments will step in to protect them.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

Many economists worry more about the second problem: credit. If firms cannot get their hands on finance, they cannot grow so easily. On March 22nd Jerome Powell, chairman of the Federal Reserve, referred to a â€œvery large body of literatureâ€ when asked about the connection between tighter credit conditions and economic activity. In the years after the global financial crisis of 2007-09, broken credit markets held back both short-term economic recovery and long-term productivity growth.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

After the collapse of svb, capital markets essentially froze. From March 11th-19th American corporations issued no new investment-grade bonds, having issued a daily average of $5bn in January and February. This caused consternation. But fewer people noticed that the market has since picked up. In recent days Brown-Forman, which makes Jack Danielâ€™s whiskey among other tipples, and NiSource, a big utility firm, have raised large amounts of money in debt markets. Although spreads on corporate bonds rose a little after the collapse of svb, they too have fallen back in recent days. Companies may have briefly held off issuing new debt to check that the coast was clear. It seems likely that March 2023 will turn out to be a fairly
average month for corporate-debt issuance.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

Damage to the banking system will almost certainly prove more consequential. Since the start of March global banksâ€™ share prices have tumbled by a sixth. Academic evidence suggests that falling share prices tend to hit loan growth. Banks may also cut back on lending if they see deposit outflows, or if they need to raise capital because investors doubt their safety. Indeed, banks across the rich world already appear to be tightening standards. The hit to bank lending implies a growth drag of around 0.4 percentage points in both America and the euro area, according to a new paper by Goldman Sachs. The turmoil may have hit American banks harder, but the euro-zone economy is more dependent on bank lending. That could cut global growth yet further, from 2.5% to something more like 2%.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

Although the recent banking turmoil is hardly good news, it is unlikely to push the world economy over the edge. True, things could yet deteriorate. The discovery of another rotten bank could cause a downward spiral. Banks will take time to rebuild balance-sheets and get lending. Rising interest rates will continue to impede growth until central bankers judge their work done.

ğŸ•ç‚¹å‡»æŸ¥çœ‹ç¿»è¯‘

ç°åœ¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰

But there are forces working in the other direction, too. One is the rebound of China. Economists expect the worldâ€™s second-largest economy to have grown by over 7% year on year in the second quarter of the year. Meanwhile, supply-chain bottlenecks have mostly disappeared and energy prices have fallen. Do not be surprised if the world economyâ€™s unusual resilience continues.

entry.title: How to use ChatGPT in China
entry.content:
Summary

Someone want to use ChatGPT to get some intreseting things.
Umm, I donâ€™t have some words want to say, letâ€™s go!

1. Preparation

Please make sure you have a VPN or something to surf the internet freely.
I will try to write some articles to teach you how to do this in the future, but right now, I donâ€™t have anything.

2. Have a Gmail

First, u can use your outlook email to create the Gmail account. And the outlook account can be created by your QQ email. This is done for that you can use a Chinese phone number to do these things. You can use a Chinese phone number to get a QQ account, then you can get everything.
So, you can have a Gmail follow:

  1. Use your Chinese phone number get a QQ account.
  2. Use your QQ account open a QQ-email as â€œxxxxxx@qq.comâ€œ.
  3. Use your QQ-email to create a outlook account.
  4. Use your outlook account to create a Gmail account.
  • Search for Gmail registration in Google, and enter the registration interface of Gmail registration. The URL as: https://support.google.com/mail/answer/56256?hl=zh-Hans
  • Itâ€™s the most important change to your browser language to English, Many peaple failed to register their Gmail account because it !
  • Then, enter your email regisratration information, here you can fill in the corresponding information normally.
  • Select country as China, If you donâ€™t do this step or previous step, then when you enter the phone number, the system will prompt you: This number cannot be use for verification.
  • And now you can get a Gmail account !

3. Get GPT account

If you have a gmail now, you can begin at this step

The registration of ChatGPT mainly includes the following steps, which must be carried out in strict order, otherwise it cannot be used.

  1. Find the www.openai.com, can enter it.
  2. Select the â€œproductâ€ option in the top directory bar. And choose the â€œChatGPTâ€ in there.
  3. Then select the â€œSign upâ€ option. -> â€œCreate an OpenAI accountâ€ -> â€œcontinue with Googleâ€

Once youâ€™ve completed email verification and registered your ChatGPT account as the first step, youâ€™re not quite ready to use ChatGPT properly yet, because you still need to verify your phone number. Without passing the phone verification, you wonâ€™t be able to access ChatGPTâ€™s services.

Due to restrictions from OpenAI, phone numbers from mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Google Voice virtual numbers cannot be used.

At this point, you will need to use the next step of the verification platform.

4. verification platform

You can get some other platform in internet, and I use the sms-activate.org.

  1. Register an account on sms-activate.org using your own email and complete the email verification process.
  2. Open your email to check for the verification email and click to confirm your sms-activate.org account verification.
  3. Log in to sms-activate.org and click the recharge button in the upper right corner to add credit. Scroll down to find Alipay and it is recommended to recharge $0.2 (top up more if necessary).
  4. After recharging, return to the homepage and search for the keyword â€œopenâ€ to find the temporary number purchase link for OpenAI verification code.
  5. Copy the temporary number in the activation area on the right side and paste it into the OpenAI verification code receiving area.
  6. Then click to send the verification code in OpenAIâ€™s page and receive the code on the platform (it may be slow sometimes, please be patient), and fill in the code to complete the ChatGPT phone verification process.

5. Log in to your ChatGPT account and get started

Due to frequent issues such as freezing, unsupported operations, and disconnections on the web version of OpenAI, I recommend downloading the desktop application version of ChatGPT. Although we can directly log in and use ChatGPT on the webpage, this is not an official software of OpenAI, but rather a hobbyistâ€™s own compilation.

The download URL as: https://github.com/lencx/ChatGPT.
